dataList.content: The door is shut.
Something just occurred to me.
That a heavy, adamantine door stood between Sancho and I, tightly shut.
Whatever I said wouldn't reach her, and she had no wish to open the door. We stood there in a stalemate.
The Sinners would conceal their troubles, shy away from attempts to understand them, but... in the end, they all wanted something.
There was this certain faith that I, as their manager, would be able to do something for them.
Or at least that they would find their wishes granted at the end of each of their flow.
Yes. They all had dreams.
He no longer wanted to be an outcast. She wanted to be special. He wanted to confront his past.
He wanted to change. She wanted to sail onward, unanchored. He wanted to mend the two hearts broken apart.
And every time, I reached out. I cried out loud each of their dreams to them, and, with some luck, managed to turn them away from the brink.
But... to Don Quixote, whose dream has already ended... Only now do I realize that I have nothing to give her, nothing to tell her.
My role stopped at breaking through each Sinner's barriers to retrieve their lost dreams, squeezing them past the doors to their hearts that remained open still, no matter how narrow the gaps were.
I have never given them something new to dream about.

dataList.place: Fathoms of Ego - La Mancha Eye
dataList.content: <Don... Quixote...>
I'll tell you again. That is not who I am.
That fool who used to twinkle her eyes at you, shoving some ridiculous idea of a dream before you is dead.
... Has Don Quixote's dream ended?
Has the dream of the other Don Quixote, who lies there with his body impaled by so many stakes... ended?
What if the dream still... continues?
<Sinclair...?>
My dream...
It ripened and ripened until the rot set in. Thus it fell to the earth and burst.
It is broken. All that remains is the decaying carcass of the dream.
Sancho's lifeless eyes gaze into the distant hollow, seeing nothing in the futility that extends far beyond the horizon.
But... Sinclair redirects her gaze toward himself.
La Manchaland manifests to devour humans, yeah... but it eventually disappears again.
Look, on one hand, it's trying to hurt us humans. But on the other hand... it keeps trying to hide away, too.
Even as he lies there, his body torn apart by thousands of stakes... he's been trying.
Perhaps your 'Father'... even he— Maybe he—
This... is what I think we must do.
... We have to go back.
To the birthplace of that dream.
The tightly shut door suddenly shook.
And in front of it stood Sinclair.
A familiar red sign, though incomplete, briefly flickered from his forehead...
... and a blinding white light surrounded him. Sinclair was...
<The Knight of the White Moon.>
... Bari.
Ba...ri...
I haven't... uttered that name... in such a long time.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: A human. At my mansion.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: A-apologies, your worship. We should never have let her through, but she... she wields all kinds of fantastical weapons. She demanded to be granted audience with you, Father.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: A Bloodfiend Hunter, are you? And you've managed to break through my Children's vigilance?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... I commend your skill, human. It cannot have been easy.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: So, what is it that you seek from this audience?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Is your wish... to be obliterated without a trace? Or is it to join my Family?
... Neither.
I am here to challenge you to a duel.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... A duel.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: I am not like the other Bloodfiends; I have no interest in killing humans for sport.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: However, I am also not so generous a Bloodfiend to let a human who dared to walk into her own doom simply saunter away without consequences.
Humans and Bloodfiends are at war out there. Did you know that?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Just a pit fight between unquenchable Bloodfiends and humans who learned to transmute their hatred into delight.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: I care not for such degeneracy.
Why do you refuse to take a side?
Should a Family of your might take a side... it would mean the decisive end of the war.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Haven't I already told you? Or does your fleeting human life require a simpler explanation?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: I would prefer not to dirty my clothes in a pit fight. I refuse to bring myself down to that level.
... Is that so.
I... am here to do one of two things. One, convince you. Or two, should my first option prove unfeasible, slay you.
Because you are more dangerous than both of them when you're sitting here and doing nothing.
So, duel me.
You won't get a chance like this again.
Because I know exactly what you seek.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Aha...

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Not even I am privy to that knowledge...

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... yet a human, who knows me not, who has only met me for the first time today, claims to know that?
I know you Bloodfiends.
Those blessed with longer lives than humans, yet cursed to live in greater miseries for every second of that longer life.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: I just changed the carpets of this hall. I do not wish to dirty it with lowly human blood.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Leave, and my Children outside this mansion will deal with you.
Should you employ your Children to kill me...
You will never learn the source of your suffering. You will remain unchanging, stagnant, steeped in your misery...
... until one day, the memory of this moment returns to you as regret.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: ... Father.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: If you would allow me, I will quietly take care of this interloper.
Grab your weapon.
Answer my duel...
... and I promise you upon my honor as a Fixer, that I will grant you what you truly seek.
I can... give you...

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: No human, let alone a Bloodfiend, has ever matched me evenly in strength.
Then I suppose I shall have the honor of being the first human to do so.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... How intriguing.
The duel continued for three days.
Three days without a victor.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: ... Why not take a brief respite?

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: It has been three days.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... Three days?

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: Yes, there's been three sunrises and sunsets. I'm quite certain that makes it three days.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: But we are yet to decide a victor.
... Too bad.
At times like these, we must each take enough rest to recover...
... and duel again at a later date. I will return.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: You would stop the battle before it ends, allow your enemy to rest... and even promise to reconvene at a later date?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Who decided that these odd rules would become laws?
Fixers.
It's a law of the Fixers.
... Father allowed that human to leave. He did not even sic us Children on her, and that was that.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: Will you truly let her leave, just like that? A human who so insolently warned you, of all Bloodfiends, that she would return?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: It is their 'law' she says.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Here she is again, Sancho. Go tell her that your Father is indisposed today and has no time to spare for a duel.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: Go tell her yourself.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: I am growing tired of this.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: What joy does that woman get out of this altercation? She could have at least had the courtesy to arrive at our gates with hands full of refreshments...

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: How should I know?

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: What I am certain of, is that this intruder will never leave us alone until we open our gates.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: By the... why did I ever agree to something so vexatious?

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: It is about time we put an end to this, Father.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: I find no joy in telling you this, but...

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: ... It does not befit your reputation to be locked in a duel with a mere human for so long.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: The other Children are... saying things.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... You will understand the pain of dealing with Children when you make Kindreds of your own.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: How many times have I told you? I refuse to do such a thing.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: How harsh you are.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Worry not. I intend to put an end to this today. I have been planning to do so for a while.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: Are you certain that you do not require my assistance?

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: I should be enough to tip the scales in your favor.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: It is all right.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: This is a duel, is it not? A duel must be fair and just.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: Is that not what she said last time, verbatim?

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: Something about the... laws of Fixers.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: ... So, what exactly are Fixers?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... I do not know.
That absurd duel continued with no end in sight.
And I found myself measuring the time, like some... referee.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: It is time.
Phew~ That was close. I thought we'd finally have a victor in this duel.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... I would like to ask you something.
Yeah?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: What, pray... is a Fixer?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: What is this 'Fixer', that has made you so pertinacious and... stubborn?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: You have mentioned their laws on our first bout as well... Is the honor of Fixers so significant that you would wager your life on it?
... I can tell you if you want.
And they both simultaneously lowered their weapons.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: You're looking forward to her arrival now, aren't you? You are waiting for her.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: The fault lies with the human. How dare she cut off her story short right at the climax?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Ah, she's here. She's here! Let her in, will you?

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: So what happened to that fool whose rope snapped at that exact moment?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: No, I must know what happened to the siblings first.
The fool who hung onto a rotten strand of rope fell to the earth, and the siblings lived happily ever after.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: What an exciting tale that was. My hands had grown so sodden from the sheer suspense.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... Sancho.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: When did you sidle up so close to our conversation?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Bari, do you recall the place you told me of upon our last meeting?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: This 'amusement park'.
Mhm.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Will you speak to me of it again?
Haah... Father, this is the seventh time—

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Yet no books on heroic tales ever mention such a thing as an 'amusement park'.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Well, then? Tell me, describe the sight.
Children enter there, holding tightly onto their parents' hands.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: What of their expressions?
Practically radiant with the happiest, brightest smiles in the world.
All wear pretty headbands or elaborate masks.
And they play such catchy, exciting music all year-round.
People dance to the music, too.
Its guests are free to do whatever they want.
Enter a game of marksmanship at the shooting range. Explore a spooky haunted mansion.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: I... I can't say I get the point of all this.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: What of this... 'ride'?
This is called a carousel. The visitors each ride upon a steed that goes in circles.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: They ride on horses only to go in circles? How utterly devoid of meaning.
And this here is called an 'observation wheel'. Humans use it to view the sights from a higher elevation.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: Not only did they craft a giant, its size thousandfold of humans, but also dare to enter its body? What a splendid method by which one may overcome their fears.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: You are seriously misunderstanding what this is.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... I have conceived an idea most ingenious.

dataList.title: Family
dataList.content: ... And this is where you stop listening to him.
So she says. Should I?

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: The pair of you are becoming alike in the worst possible ways.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: ... I wish to build one myself.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: An 'amusement park', where humans and Bloodfiends can happily coexist.

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: I shall call it...

dataList.title: Father
dataList.content: La Manchaland.
Step by step.
One.
Two.
Three. I found myself slowly becoming engrossed in her tales.
That is how his dream... became mine...

dataList.place: Fathoms of Ego - La Mancha Eye
dataList.content: But it wasn't long...
... before it was broken and cast aside.
Like my Father.
Yet, there exists an understanding beyond sight.
Why, why does La Manchaland not exist in perpetuity, but seek to vanish only within hours of its manifestation?
It can only be your Father's final, lingering conveyance of his will.
Father gave me Rocinante so that I may embark on an adventure of my own.
But none of my tales were real. They were all... fake.
Once I drank from the River of Oblivion... once I imprisoned myself in a cell of my own making... I spent day after day immersed in these books of 'Fixers'.
And that has tainted my story with vacuous lies and hyperbole.
What was it that you have always said to me?
That it was about time I woke up from my delusions.
Yes. I suppose now is the time I came to my senses.
